refnamediv.refpurpose: probe a GPS for type, send-cycle time and accuracy information

refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: gpsprobe samples the NMEA data stream from a GPS and attempts to deduce various interesting pieces of information, including:

listitem.para: the GPS type (what chipset it uses)
the inventory of NMEA sentence types it emits

refsect1.para: In addition, if the GPS is getting position fixes, gpsprobe generates a scattergram from them and plots a probable-error circle. This data is only meaningful if the GPS is held stationary while gpsprobe is running.
The report and scattergram is generated as a gnuplot1 script to standard output. View it with gnuplot -persist <foo> where <foo> should be replaced with the name of the plot script.
Note: gpsprobe needs access to the raw GPS device. Therefore gpsd must not be running when you call gpsprobe. You will probably have to run as superuser to get access to the device.

refsect1.title: OPTIONS
refsect1.para: The -b option sets the baud rate at which to connect. The default is 4800.
The -n option sets the number of packets to sample. The default is 100.
The -h option makes gpsprobe print a usage message and exit.
The argument, if given, sets the name of the GPS device. The default is /dev/gps.

refsect1.title: BUGS AND LIMITAIONS
refsect1.para: This program handles only straight NMEA devices; it won't handle either Rockwell or SiRF binary protocols.
